processed_hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Qurrah ibn Iyas: When the people of al-Sham (the Levant) become corrupt, there is no good in you. And a group from my Ummah will continue fighting for the truth, appearing victorious, until the command of Allah, the Mighty and Majestic, comes to them while they are upon that.

narrators.name: Abu Bakr
narrators.full_name: Abu Bakr ibn Abi Shaybah Ibrahim ibn Uthman al-Kufi

narrators.name: Yazid ibn Harun
narrators.full_name: Yazid ibn Harun ibn Yazid al-Wasiti
narrators.alternative_names: Yazid al-Wasiti, Yazid ibn Harun al-Basri

narrators.name: Shu'bah
narrators.full_name: Shu'bah ibn al-Hajjaj ibn al-Ward al-Ataki al-Azdi

narrators.name: Mu'awiyah ibn Qurrah
narrators.full_name: Mu'awiyah ibn Qurrah ibn Iyas al-Muzani

narrators.name: Qurrah ibn Iyas
narrators.full_name: Qurrah ibn Iyas ibn Khalid ibn Saad al-Muzani

narrators.name: Prophet Muhammad ﷺ
narrators.full_name: Muhammad ibn Abdullah ibn Abd al-Muttalib ibn Hashim

chainIssues: Mu'awiyah ibn Qurrah uses 'an (عَنْ) which may indicate indirect transmission. However, given he is known to have narrated directly from his father, this should be acceptable. Mu'awiyah is graded as Saduq Yukhtī - occasionally erring, but not severely problematic. The use of 'an with a direct relative (father) is commonly accepted in hadith methodology.

potential_issues.issue: Indirect transmission term ('an) from Mu'awiyah ibn Qurrah to his father
potential_issues.impact: While 'an typically indicates potential indirectness, when a son narrates from his father using this term, it is generally acceptable as direct hearing is presumed between close family members. However, some scholars may require explicit hearing terms.

potential_issues.issue: Mu'awiyah ibn Qurrah's grade is Saduq Yukhtī (occasionally erring)
potential_issues.impact: This narrator occasionally makes errors in transmission, which introduces moderate weakness to the isnad. However, given the overall strength of the chain (Shu'bah, Yazid, and Abu Bakr are all highly reliable), the hadith is not significantly compromised.

Topics: Corruption of the people of al-Sham (the Levant)
Continuation of the Ummah fighting for truth until the Hour
Signs of the Hour - state of the Levant
Promise of divine aid to believers who fight for truth

processed_hadiths.english_translation: Section heading: Mention of Qurrah al-Muzani (may Allah be pleased with him)

narrators.name: Compiler/Editor
narrators.full_name: Unknown Compiler
reliabilityIssues: This is a section header, not an actual hadith

chainIssues: This entry is a section header (maqtu') with no actual hadith chain or transmission. It serves as a chapter/section divider in the original manuscript.

potential_issues.issue: Not an actual hadith - section header only
potential_issues.impact: Cannot be analyzed for authenticity as it contains no hadith content, no isnad, and no matn. This is merely a title indicating the next section discusses the companion Qurrah al-Muzani.

processed_hadiths.IISGrade: Disconnections But All Narrators Are Ok
Topics: Section header - Introduction of companion Qurrah al-Muzani

processed_hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by an uncle of Mu'awiyah ibn Qurrah: The Companions asked the Prophet ﷺ, 'What do you consider al-Raqub (the deprived) among you?' They said, 'O Messenger of Allah, the deprived is the one who has no wealth and no status.' The Prophet ﷺ said, 'That is not it. Rather, the deprived is the one who dies and leaves many children, so that is the deprived one.' [This continues in the following sections with definitions of the strong one and the poor one]

narrators.name: Zakariyya ibn Yahya
narrators.full_name: Zakariyya ibn Yahya ibn Sulayman al-Wasiti
reliabilityIssues: little known; insufficient documentation of reliability

narrators.name: Abd al-Hakim ibn Mansur
narrators.full_name: Abd al-Hakim ibn Mansur ibn al-Hajjaj

narrators.name: Abd al-Malik ibn Umayr
narrators.full_name: Abd al-Malik ibn Umayr ibn Abd al-Rahman ibn Abi Sacsacah
narrators.alternative_names: Abd al-Malik al-Ansari, Ibn Abi Sacsacah

narrators.name: Mu'awiyah ibn Qurrah
narrators.full_name: Mu'awiyah ibn Qurrah ibn Iyas al-Muzani

narrators.name: Abu Salamah
narrators.full_name: Abu Salamah al-Himsi or al-Harani (Uncle of Mu'awiyah ibn Qurrah)
narrators.alternative_names: Unknown - only identified as 'uncle of Mu'awiyah'

narrators.name: Prophet Muhammad ﷺ
narrators.full_name: Muhammad ibn Abdullah ibn Abd al-Muttalib ibn Hashim

chainIssues: The chain contains multiple weak points: (1) Zakariyya ibn Yahya is Majhul al-Hal (little known) - he appears to be from Ubullah and may be identified only by this collection; (2) Abd al-Hakim ibn Mansur is Saduq Yahim (prone to confusion); (3) Abd al-Malik ibn Umayr is Saduq Yugrib (his narrations are sometimes odd/strange); (4) The last narrator 'an uncle of Mu'awiyah' is weakly identified and may be Majhul al-'ayn (only one person narrates from him) - he is described only as 'uncle' and is difficult to identify with certainty.

potential_issues.issue: Zakariyya ibn Yahya is Majhul al-Hal - insufficiently documented narrator
potential_issues.impact: The first narrator in the chain is little known. While he appears in narrations, his reliability has not been thoroughly documented by hadith scholars. This weakens the chain, though it does not make it clearly false.

potential_issues.issue: Multiple narrators with documented reliability concerns
potential_issues.impact: Abd al-Hakim ibn Mansur is Saduq Yahim (prone to confusion), and Abd al-Malik ibn Umayr is Saduq Yugrib (his narrations are sometimes strange/odd). The accumulation of these issues throughout the chain indicates weakness.

potential_issues.issue: The final narrator before Mu'awiyah is not clearly identified - 'an uncle of Mu'awiyah ibn Qurrah'
potential_issues.impact: The uncle's name is not given explicitly, only identified by relation. This makes it difficult to verify his status. He could be Majhul al-'ayn (only one person narrates from him). This is a significant issue in hadith transmission.

potential_issues.issue: Use of 'an (عَنْ) in indirect transmission contexts
potential_issues.impact: The use of 'an from Mu'awiyah to his unknown uncle and from the uncle to the Prophet ﷺ introduces potential gaps. Combined with the weak narrators, this compounds the reliability concerns.

Topics: Definition of al-Raqub (the childless deprived)
Definition of al-Shadid (the truly strong - one who controls anger)
Definition of al-Faqir (the truly poor - one who dies with much wealth but no charity)
Meanings of strength and poverty in Islamic perspective

processed_hadiths.english_translation: [Continuation of Hadith 1266] He ﷺ asked, 'What do you consider the truly strong among you?' They said, 'The strong is the one of great physical strength.' He ﷺ said, 'That is not it. Rather, the truly strong is the one who, when filled with anger, controls himself. So that is the truly strong one.'

narrators.name: [From Hadith 1266]
narrators.full_name: [Same chain as Hadith 1266 - this is a continuation]
narrators.transmissionTermMeaning: He said (reporting continuation of same hadith)

chainIssues: This entry (1267) is a continuation of the hadith in entry 1266 with the same chain. It is not a separate hadith but rather the continuation of the same narration discussing the definition of al-Shadid (the truly strong). The phrase '/34 قَالَ' indicates continuation within the same transmission.

potential_issues.issue: This is a continuation of hadith 1266, not a separate hadith
potential_issues.impact: Hadith 1267 should not be analyzed separately from 1266. Together they form one complete hadith about the definitions of al-Raqub, al-Shadid, and al-Faqir. They share the same chain and should be considered as one transmission.

Topics: Part of hadith about definitions of strength and poverty

processed_hadiths.english_translation: [Continuation of Hadith 1266] He ﷺ asked, 'What do you consider the truly poor among you?' They said, 'The poor is the one who has nothing and has no status.' He ﷺ said, 'That is not it. Rather, the truly poor is the one who dies and leaves much wealth yet has not sent anything forward (for the Hereafter).'

narrators.name: [From Hadith 1266]
narrators.full_name: [Same chain as Hadith 1266 - this is a continuation]
narrators.transmissionTermMeaning: He said (reporting continuation of same hadith)

chainIssues: This entry (1268) is the second continuation of the hadith in entry 1266 with the same chain. It completes the hadith with the definition of al-Faqir (the truly poor). Like 1267, this is not a separate hadith but part of the same transmission.

potential_issues.issue: This is a continuation of hadith 1266, not a separate hadith
potential_issues.impact: Hadith 1268 is the final part of the hadith that begins in 1266. All three entries (1266, 1267, 1268) share the same isnad and should be analyzed as one complete hadith.

Topics: Part of hadith about definitions of strength and poverty

potential_issues.issue: Not an actual hadith - section header only

processed_hadiths.IISGrade: Disconnections But All Narrators Are Ok
Topics: Section header - Introduction of companion Abdullah ibn Sargis al-Muzani

processed_hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Abdullah ibn Sargis: I came to the Prophet ﷺ and he knew what I wanted. He removed his garment from his shoulders, and I moved around until I stood behind him and saw the seal on the blade of his shoulder, surrounded by moles like the gathering of the palm [of the hand]. Then I moved around until I stood in front of him and said, 'May Allah forgive you, O Messenger of Allah,' and he said, 'And you.' They said, 'Did the Messenger of Allah ﷺ seek forgiveness for you?' He said, 'And for you [all].'

narrators.name: Abu al-Rabi
narrators.full_name: Abu al-Rabi Sulayman ibn Dawud al-Kalai

narrators.name: Hammad ibn Zayd
narrators.full_name: Hammad ibn Zayd ibn Dinar al-Azdi

narrators.name: Asim al-Ahwal
narrators.full_name: Asim ibn Bajdala al-Asadi al-Kufi
reliabilityIssues: becomes confused when narrating from memory

narrators.name: Abdullah ibn Sargis
narrators.full_name: Abdullah ibn Sargis ibn al-Hajjaj al-Muzani
narrators.alternative_names: Abdullah al-Muzani, Abu Abdur Rahman al-Muzani

narrators.name: Prophet Muhammad ﷺ
narrators.full_name: Muhammad ibn Abdullah ibn Abd al-Muttalib ibn Hashim

chainIssues: Asim al-Ahwal is graded as Saduq and is known to become confused when narrating from memory. While his hadith is not rejected, it carries moderate weakness. The chain is generally acceptable but not strong.

narrators.name: Ibrahim ibn Hajjaj
narrators.full_name: Ibrahim ibn Hajjaj ibn Uthman al-Basri

narrators.name: Abd al-Wahid ibn Ziyad
narrators.full_name: Abd al-Wahid ibn Ziyad ibn Mansur al-Basri

narrators.name: Asim al-Ahwal
narrators.full_name: Asim ibn Bajdala al-Asadi al-Kufi
reliabilityIssues: becomes confused when narrating from memory

narrators.name: Abdullah ibn Sargis
narrators.full_name: Abdullah ibn Sargis ibn al-Hajjaj al-Muzani
narrators.alternative_names: Abdullah al-Muzani, Abu Abdur Rahman al-Muzani

narrators.name: Prophet Muhammad ﷺ
narrators.full_name: Muhammad ibn Abdullah ibn Abd al-Muttalib ibn Hashim

chainIssues: Second chain has two problematic points: (1) Abd al-Wahid ibn Ziyad is Saduq with proneness to mistakes; (2) Asim al-Ahwal is Saduq and known for confusion in narration. Uses 'an with Asim al-Ahwal, which may indicate indirectness. These combine to create a weak chain.

potential_issues.issue: Two variant transmission paths both converge on the same hadith about the Seal of Prophethood
potential_issues.impact: The existence of two different chains strengthens the hadith overall, as they corroborate the same core incident. However, both chains contain weak points.

potential_issues.issue: Asim al-Ahwal appears in both chains and is Saduq with known confusion issues
potential_issues.impact: While his narrations are not rejected, they are not of the highest quality. His presence in both chains is notable.

potential_issues.issue: Abd al-Wahid ibn Ziyad in the second chain is prone to mistakes
potential_issues.impact: This further weakens the second chain, though the core material from Abdullah ibn Sargis remains reliable.

Topics: Description of the Seal of Prophethood on the Prophet's ﷺ back
Physical appearance of the Prophet ﷺ
Incident of Abdullah ibn Sargis viewing the Prophet ﷺ
Prophet ﷺ seeking forgiveness for Abdullah ibn Sargis

processed_hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Abdullah ibn Sargis: Verily, the good appearance, the humble manner, and the moderation are one part of twenty-four parts of Prophethood.

narrators.name: Nasir ibn Ali
narrators.full_name: Nasir ibn Ali ibn Abd al-Aziz al-Ahnasi al-Kufi

narrators.name: Nuh ibn Qais
narrators.full_name: Nuh ibn Qais al-Samarqandi

narrators.name: Abdullah ibn Imran
narrators.full_name: Abdullah ibn Imran al-Himsi

narrators.name: Asim al-Ahwal
narrators.full_name: Asim ibn Bajdala al-Asadi al-Kufi
reliabilityIssues: becomes confused when narrating from memory

narrators.name: Abdullah ibn Sargis
narrators.full_name: Abdullah ibn Sargis ibn al-Hajjaj al-Muzani
narrators.alternative_names: Abdullah al-Muzani, Abu Abdur Rahman al-Muzani

narrators.name: Prophet Muhammad ﷺ
narrators.full_name: Muhammad ibn Abdullah ibn Abd al-Muttalib ibn Hashim

chainIssues: This chain contains significant weaknesses: (1) Abdullah ibn Imran is Layyin al-Hadith (weak narrator) - this is a serious problem; (2) Asim al-Ahwal is Saduq with confusion issues; (3) Multiple 'an transmission terms create potential gaps; (4) The final term 'anna' indicates potential disconnection. The presence of Layyin al-Hadith narrator significantly weakens this chain.

potential_issues.issue: Abdullah ibn Imran is Layyin al-Hadith (weak in hadith)
potential_issues.impact: This is a significant reliability problem. The narrator is considered weak and unreliable by hadith scholars. This substantially weakens the entire chain.

potential_issues.issue: Multiple indirect transmission terms ('an) and disconnection term ('anna) in the chain
potential_issues.impact: These create potential gaps in the transmission. When combined with weak narrators, they significantly compromise the hadith's reliability.

potential_issues.issue: Nuh ibn Qais and Asim al-Ahwal both have documented reliability concerns
potential_issues.impact: The accumulation of weak points throughout the chain indicates this hadith is of low reliability.

Topics: Good appearance and manners as part of Prophethood
Humble bearing and moderation as virtuous traits

processed_hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Abdullah ibn Mas'ud: The Messenger of Allah ﷺ forbade: the breaking of the money of the Muslims that is in circulation among them except due to necessity.

narrators.name: Abu Bakr ibn Abi Shaybah
narrators.full_name: Abu Bakr ibn Abi Shaybah Abdullah ibn Muhammad ibn Abi Shaybah
narrators.alternative_names: Abdullah ibn Muhammad ibn Abi Shaybah

narrators.name: Mu'tamir ibn Sulayman
narrators.full_name: Mu'tamir ibn Sulayman ibn Tarhan al-Tajjibi

narrators.name: Muhammad ibn Fada
narrators.full_name: Muhammad ibn Fada' ibn Muhammad

narrators.name: Fada ibn Muhammad
narrators.full_name: Fada' ibn Muhammad ibn Fada'

narrators.name: Alqamah ibn Abdullah
narrators.full_name: Alqamah ibn Abdullah ibn Mas'ud al-Hamdani

narrators.name: Abdullah ibn Mas'ud
narrators.full_name: Abdullah ibn Mas'ud ibn Ghafil al-Hamdani al-Kufi
narrators.transmissionTermMeaning: From (potentially indirect transmission, though Alqamah is his son)
narrators.alternative_names: Abdullah al-Hamdani, Sahib al-Kutf (Owner of the Boot)

narrators.name: Prophet Muhammad ﷺ
narrators.full_name: Muhammad ibn Abdullah ibn Abd al-Muttalib ibn Hashim

chainIssues: The chain goes through intermediaries Muhammad ibn Fada and his father Fada (both Saduq). While both are acceptable, there are two consecutive indirect transmission terms ('an) between Mu'tamir and the final reporters. The chain is generally solid given the prominence of Thiqah narrators at the beginning (Abu Bakr ibn Abi Shaybah and Mu'tamir).

potential_issues.issue: Multiple indirect transmission terms ('an) without explicit hearing claims
potential_issues.impact: While the narrators are reliable, the use of multiple 'an terms without direct hearing claims creates slight ambiguity. However, this does not significantly weaken the chain given the overall narrator reliability.

potential_issues.issue: Muhammad ibn Fada and his father are Saduq grade narrators
potential_issues.impact: These narrators are reliable but not of the highest tier. Their presence in the middle of the chain creates moderate weakness.

Topics: Prohibition of breaking the coinage/money in circulation among Muslims
Exception in case of necessity
Financial rules and regulations in Islamic law

processed_hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Iyas ibn Abdullah al-Muzani: I heard that people were selling water. He said, 'Do not sell water, for I heard the Messenger of Allah ﷺ forbidding that it be sold.'

narrators.name: Abu Bakr ibn Abi Shaybah
narrators.full_name: Abu Bakr ibn Abi Shaybah Abdullah ibn Muhammad ibn Abi Shaybah
narrators.alternative_names: Abdullah ibn Muhammad ibn Abi Shaybah

narrators.name: Sufyan
narrators.full_name: Sufyan ibn Sa'id al-Thawri

narrators.name: Amr ibn Dinar
narrators.full_name: Amr ibn Dinar al-Makki

narrators.name: Abu al-Minhal
narrators.full_name: Abu al-Minhal al-Asadi, whose name was 'Amid or similar

narrators.name: Iyas ibn Abdullah al-Muzani
narrators.full_name: Iyas ibn Abdullah ibn Harmulah al-Muzani
narrators.transmissionTermMeaning: I heard (explicit hearing term - strongest connection)

narrators.name: Prophet Muhammad ﷺ
narrators.full_name: Muhammad ibn Abdullah ibn Abd al-Muttalib ibn Hashim

chainIssues: The chain contains generally reliable narrators. Abu Bakr ibn Abi Shaybah and Sufyan al-Thawri are both Thiqah Thabt. Amr ibn Dinar is also Thiqah Thabt. Abu al-Minhal is Saduq but acceptable. Iyas ibn Abdullah uses the strong term 'sami'tu' (I heard), which strengthens the connection. The chain is solid overall.

potential_issues.issue: Abu al-Minhal is Saduq grade, which is below Thiqah
potential_issues.impact: While not severely problematic, this introduces slight weakness to an otherwise strong chain.

potential_issues.issue: Two 'an transmission terms without explicit hearing claims (Amr ibn Dinar and Abu al-Minhal)
potential_issues.impact: These are mitigated by the strong narrators at the beginning and the explicit 'sami'tu' from Iyas ibn Abdullah.

Topics: Prohibition of selling water
Generosity and public welfare in Islamic perspective
Water distribution and pricing regulations
